story:
The Story

Mary Wanjiru Maina, aka Ciru (short for Wanjiru), was born in 1979 in Mathare slum to an alcoholic mother in 1979. At the age of 10 Ciru ran away from home and joined the hundreds of thousands of children who inhabited the streets of Nairobi. "They preferred the streets to home...". (New York Times, "In the Hell of  a Nairobi Slum, A Priest Offers Hope, 26th November 1984). Street children in Nairobi in the late 80's and 90's survived by scavenging for food, begging, and getting high from sniffing glue/gasoline. For 3 years this was Ciru's life.

Life on the street came to an end for Ciru when she became one of many children that joined the Undugu Society Street Children Rehabilitation programme. The Society was founded by Father Arnold Grol in 1973; in Father Grol's words the mission of the society was to "make living more than a matter of existing" and to empower poor, marginalised and vulnerable people to live life with dignity.

One of the key strategies to achieve this for street children was to place them in schools where they could learn vocational skills that they could utilise to earn a living. Ciru was taken to the Meru Technical Training Institute where she spent 2 years learning to sew. When Ciru left the Training Institute she returned to Nairobi, and began looking for work.

In her search for employment Ciru was drawn to the street food vendors who seemed to earn an enticing income from cooking and selling street food. What was most attractive to Ciru was the food itself, and she narrowed her job search to food related work. Ciru eventually managed to secure work as a kitchen hand in a number of restaurants in Nairobi. It is in these kitchens that Ciru confirmed that her passion was for food: she paid close attention to the way chefs in these restaurants would prepare delicious, tasty, yet simple dishes using inexpensive ingredients.

In between jobs as a kitchen hand, Ciru would market herself as a cook, and managed to secure a number of catering jobs where she was able to put what she had learned as a kitchen hand to practice. With time Ciru became known as the "go-to-person" for catering jobs in Mathare. Ciru has built a reputation for herself in Mathare as a cook who can prepare delicious dishes for any number of people with any budget. She has provided catering services to a number of residents both within and outside of Mathare, to a number of churches, and for a number of events including weddings and funerals.

Ciru has come to realise that the catering business is a lucrative option, even for someone who has had limited access to formal education. As Ciru says, in the catering business, all you need to be successful is a passion for food, and a willingness to learn. Ciru is keen to open a School of Cookery in Mathare and offer youth who have a passion for food the opportunity to learn how to make a living doing what they love: to cook.

Why a School of Cookery:

As a former street child, Ciru understands the limited options for advanced learning that are available to children who grow up in low income neighbourhoods such as Mathare. Whilst the government of Kenya has extended free primary school education and subsidized secondary school education to all Kenyans, a number of children remain locked out of the educational system due to a number of social and economic challenges that they and their families face. 

Without a secondary school and college/university education the majority of youth in Kenya are automatically locked out of employment opportunities in the formal sector. These youth end up working  as low skilled casual labourers, and will typically earn an average of KES 8,500.00 ($86.30/£62.96) or less a month for most of their working life.

Ciru's School of Cookery will be an excellent alternative for youth who are locked out of the advanced educational system. In the words of Henrietta Inman, a pastry chef in Suffolk (http://www.henriettainman.co.uk/):

“My trade is as a pastry chef then there are carpenters, ceramicists, jewelers, actors, musicians... education is obviously extremely important too but I think having a trade/ craft to carry you throughout life is a great attribute and something to be cherished. If you can realise Ciru's dream and help her create her school, think of the amount of people who will be able to learn a trade (to be a chef!) and have it with them for the rest of their lives, earning them a living, supporting their families and hopefully enjoying it at the same time! It would be amazing”.

The food industry is now a billion dollar industry worldwide, and has been growing rapidly in Kenya. Ciru's School of Cookery will create a work force of versatile and innovative chefs who can meet the growing demand for professional chefs within Nairobi, and Kenya at large. 

Why Mathare:

-  Mathare is the second largest slum in Nairobi;

-  Anna Tibaijuka, the former Executive Director for UN-HABITAT, described Mathare as a neighbourhood “where people eke out a living in life threatening conditions, where the most basic needs are not met for the majority, and where population growth rates are the highest in Africa. Their poverty is compounded by many factors such as domestic violence, crime, drugs and alcoholism, to name a few”.

-  Very few parents in Mathare can afford to send their children to secondary school. As a result these children are forced to find work to support themselves and their families. Unfortunately a large number resort to early marriage, prostitution, drug and alcohol trafficking and other types of urban crime in an effort to survive in their hostile urban environment.

- There is no Cookery School in Mathare at present.

The picture however is not bleak: hope lives in Mathare.

Residents of Mathare have been described as “resilient and entrepreneurial”.  They “have a range of skills that allow them to survive in one of the most difficult urban environments in East Africa”. 

Ciru's School of Cookery aims to tap into this resilient, entrepreneurial spirit, and provide the youth of Mathare with the opportunity to learn a trade that will allow them not only to survive, but to thrive in the lucrative food industry.

Ciru's School of Cookery will address the following issues:

1.  Lack of access to higher level education;

2.  Youth unemployment;

3.  Poverty and other vulnerabilities that youth in Mathare face on a day to day basis.

The Model of the School:

In the first year of operation 20 students will attend an intensive 6 month cookery course for a subsidized rate of KES 15,000.00 ($152.28). For those who cannot afford this subsidized fee Ciru's School of Cookery will allocate 6 scholarships in the first year. In addition to this Ciru's School of Cookery will partner with local institutions/organisations who can provide scholarships/bursaries for additional youth to attend the 6 month cookery course.

Students will have the opportunity to learn the following: 

-  Butchery

- Fishmongery

- Hots

- Colds

-  Pastry & Bakery

Students of Ciru's School of Cookery will also have the opportunity to participate in:

-  Sourcing trips to suppliers

-  Lectures from professionals in the food industry

-  Lectures/practicals on the business aspects of running a successful food enterprise

-  One on One Personal Development and Life Skills sessions

-  Exchange Programmes

-  Internships/placements in a professional kitchen/restaurant in Nairobi

-  Post graduation progression management

How will the school sustain itself?

The school will double up as a catering company, and income generated from catering contracts will fund the running and operational costs of the School.

Teaching and catering duties will be divided as follows:

The Training and Developmental Chef (T&D Chef): will be responsible for teaching 20 students every year.

Head Chef (Ciru): will be responsible for securing catering jobs, developing menus for clients and coordinating the T&D Chef and students to cater to events for the residents of Mathare, residents of surrounding neighbourhoods, corporates and other individuals/organisations who require catering services.

The School as a Social Enterprise:

Ciru's School of Cookery will be a social enterprise with a hybrid model where the catering business is for profit, and the school itself is not for profit.

What Ciru Needs:

Ciru is currently trying to recruit financial support from individuals who can help her realise her dream to pass on her skills as a chef, and in the process empower a generation of marginalized and vulnerable youth to thrive in the food industry and in other areas of their lives.

Ciru needs to raise a total of $66,608.57. The budget is broken down below as follows:

Building and construction Cost at Pequinnos Social Hall Mathare  $15,228.43
Kitchen Equipment Cost   $12,182.74
2 Computers and 1 Printer   $3,248.73
Registration of Ciru's School of Cookery   $1,015.23
Logo Design  $ 507.61
Licences   $ 507.61
Salaries for 6 months $15,106.60
Service Charge for 6 months (as the school will be located at the Social Hall which is community structure Ciru will pay service charge to maintain the condition of the social hall rather than rent)  $  1,827.41
Ingredients for 6 months (approximately) $  6,091.37
Insurance  $ 1,218.27
Administrative Cost and Expenses $6,502.74 
5% Indiegogo Flexible Funding Fee  $3,171.83
GRAND TOTAL
  $66,608.57

Perks

Individuals who donate $100 will receive a recipe of Ciru's Signature Dish: Marinated Fried Fish served with Traditional Kunde and Ugali

Individuals who donate $500 will receive a cooking apron made from local Kitenge material and branded with Ciru's School of Cookery Logo.

If we don't reach our goal:

We have already managed to raise $15,228.43 of the total budget. This money has been pledged by Colstoun Cookery School (www.colstouncookeryschool.co.uk) and will be used to build a second floor at Pequinnos Social Hall in Mathare where the school will be located. Any additional money raised will be used to buy kitchen equipment for the school, and to meet running costs for the first 6 months of operation.

People Who Have Shaped this Project

Maggie Muthama (Director, AM Cafe www.amcafe.org)

Cameron Sinclair-Parry (Director, Colstoun Cookery School, www.colstouncookeryschool.co.uk)

Isaac Mwasa (aka Kaka, Youth Community Leader, Mathare)

Nathaniel Canuel (Up with Hope www.upwithhope.blogspot.com)

Alice Muthama (Little Acts of Kindness www.facebook.com/pages/Little-Acts-of-Kindness/... )

Risks & Challenges

Donations versus income earned:

For the first 6 months the school will be fully funded by donations. Thereafter the school will work towards decreasing dependence on donations and generating sufficient income from catering jobs in order to ensure that the school is largely self-sustaining. 

Ciru's strategy, in collaboration with AM Cafe, to address this challenge is to continue engaging in networking platforms where she can build partnerships with individuals and organisations who can support her work, and to help her to actively and successfully engage in markets that can sustain her catering business. 

Once I donate how can I keep track of how well Ciru's School of Cookery is doing:

Individuals interested in keeping track of Ciru's progress can visit the Hold My Hand Initiative Page of the AM Cafe website, where we will regularly post updates on Ciru's School of Cookery.

In addition to the above Ciru's School of Cookery will distribute a newsletter that will document progress on the project, successes, challenges and strategies to overcome challenges related to the project. To subscribe to receive this newsletter please email ciruschoolofcookery@gmail.com or maggie@amcafe.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

At present we are also looking for support in the following areas:

1. Local and International professional chefs to volunteer to teach Master classes in 2016-2017 (either long distance or in Mathare, Kenya).

2.  Restaurant owners in Nairobi to offer internships to the graduates of the School of Catering to help them gain hands on experience of working in a professional kitchen.

3. International schools of cookery to participate in exchange programmes with Ciru's School of Cookery.

If you are interested in supporting this worthwhile initiative in one of the aforementioned ways, or in any other way please contact Ciru Maina (ciruschoolofcookery@gmail.com) or Maggie Muthama (maggie@amcafe.org/www.amcafe.org) for further details.

Please hold Ciru's Hand and help her realise her dream to open a School of Cookery in Mathare.

story:
Short Summary

This is an expansion plan of an existing tax advisory firm and tax preparation firm to build tax offices nationwide.

The marketing strategy is to sell a book “The Simple Book on How to Make Money Out of Thin Air” that will include a tax coupon, credit repair coupon and next car purchase coupon valued at $250 each. The compensation plan will be generous with various bonus rounds that do not require the participants to sell more than two or require them to recruit people because it is not a multi-level-marketing scheme. 

Meyer Strategy is a Strategy Consulting Firm based in Glendale, CA serving over 3,000 clients for more than fifteen years that delivers multiplier effect solutions tailored on our clients' need on cash, tax and lifestyle worldwide.

Product / Service Line

The company provides the following products / services:

ü  Tax Advisory and Tax Preparation Services

ü  Life Insurance

ü  Meyer Organization

Meyer Organization is the marketing arm of the life insurance and tax business. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $250 thousand which will enable us to move to a new location, start the publishing and marketing of the book, programming of the pay-out system, purchase office furniture and computer equipments, office supplies, create marketing materials and train new employees to support the tax and insurance business.

The first month’s operations will generate $300 thousand of gross revenues from sale of book and Life Insurance.  We expect to provide an exit within one year and the contributors is expected to receive share in excess profits of not less than 10%.

The funds will be allocated as follows:

ü  Office Move                 $  40

ü  Programmer                    50

ü  Tax Business                  60

ü  Insurance Business     40

ü  The Simple Book          50

ü  Miscellaneous                10

                                    $ 250

As a way of saying thank you:

1.  Participants that will give $10,000 or more will receive all the perks plus a vacation trip to Hawaii. 

2.  Participants that will give $1,000 will receive one (1) collectible book with serial number for the first 100 participants plus a certificate of appreciation.

3.  Participants that will give $100 will receive one (1) collectible book  plus a certificate of appreciation.

4.  Participants that will give $25 will receive one (1) book  plus a certificate of appreciation.

5. Should the campaign not reach its targeted amount, we will use the funds for our normal daily operating expenses.  

The Impact

The campaign will build tax offices nationwide and will become an affordable office and a one stop shop for business services that will provide solutions to cash, tax and lifestyle of each and everyone of us year-round.

Risks & Challenges

The first step.  This is always the hardest step of them all.  But we already passed the initial development of the campaign.  We already have approximately $30,000 since the start of the campaign during August 2015.

Other Ways You Can Help

You could also participate by making a noise and asking your friend to participate. There are other ways to help like improving our campaign site.  We welcome any.

story:
INTRODUCTION


Emergination Africa is a non profit organisation with one aim – to develop routes to higher education for youth in Africa; regardless of circumstance or situation we will assist students to make a smooth transition to university.


VISION

Our vision is to be the pinnacle global youth organization developing young African students to create opportunities for themselves and for others. 

MISSION

Our mission is to advance Africa's transformation through global skills transfer and educational mentorship.

MOTTO

Mentoring for Africa's youth transformation. 

Students across Sub-Saharan Africa face many challenges on route to higher education and the development of skills for the global economy.

Emergination Africa recognizes the many barriers and as such has developed routes to higher education to provide as smooth a transition as possible, in the face of these challenges.

The key to a prosperous future for our youth hinges on the ability to compete on a global playing field by figuring out the best way to obtain the relevant skills, knowledge base and networks.

This crowdfunding campaign has been put together to raise funds for the development of a series of initiatives which include establishing e-conferencing hubs (EmergiHubs) on highschool campuses. These programs will allow young people and their families access to the best educational programmes and will open the door to opportunities for a productive future. 

If you are looking for a solution to you or your child’s future education, regardless of circumstance or situation Emergination Africa are here to help, by supporting this campaign you will become a part of our community and join us on our journey to empowering young African students create opportunities for themselves and for others.

OBJECTIVES

Our Key objectives are:

Goal 1: To mentor high school students to be college ready and go to college or university

We provide quality peer-to-peer mentorship on the college application process, thereby making it a reality for our students to get into the best universities in the world. We do this through connecting our students to our active network of college students around the world.


Goal 2: To provide our mentees an opportunity to network with professionals and college students from various parts of the world

Our students have the opportunity to network with professionals from various parts of the world, in particular, the U.S. through our interactive Emergination E-conferencing Global Careers Panel sessions. During these sessions students are exposed to various career fields and what it takes to be successful in those fields

Goal 3: To offer peer-to-peer and professional career advisement services to high school students in Africa

Students get the opportunity to learn about various career fields thereby enabling them to make informed decisions pertaining to degrees they want to pursue in college.  


Goal 4: To instill an idea of civic engagement and community impact in students through the implementation of practical projects in their communities

We challenge and encourage mentees to actively engage in their communities through various service projects targeted to impact the greater community and effect positive change.

OUR COMMUNITY LEADERS


  Taku Machirori

An unabashed optimist with a passion for global leadership Taku is committed to seeing Africa become self-sufficient through education and job creation. Based in San Francisco, California Taku is a business technology analyst with Deloitte Consulting and serves on the Board of Tenjo Quarry Zimbabwe. He is graduate of Morehouse College in Atlanta GA.

Favorite Quote: “If serving is beneath you, leadership is beyond you.”

 Prince Abudu


Prince Abudu is a 4th year Computer Science and Mathematics Major at Morehouse College, in Atlanta, Georgia, USA. Prince is an unabashed optimist and highly motivated student leader who has an amazing commitment to excellence, along with firm determination to achieve greatness for the greater good. In addition to being an icon of academic excellence, Prince has been recognized by the Resolution Project as young man who is socially responsible and an outstanding leader. Prince has demonstrated great interest in Information Technology as evidenced by attaining a first prize in a Hackathon for a mobile application prototype. 

Through his participation on a global level, it is no doubt that Prince is a current and future global ethical leader.


  Caleb Solomon

Caleb Solomon is from Tema, Ghana where he went to high school at the Presbyterian Boys’. He graduated from high school and got accepted to Morehouse College. At Morehouse College, he enrolled in the Dual Degree program where he major in Chemistry and Chemical Engineering. After completing his Chemistry degree within three years, he transitioned onto Columbia University where he studied Chemical Engineering and completed that in 2 years. He engaged himself in numerous extra-curricular and leadership positions while in school and currently graduated with two bachelor’s degree from Morehouse college and Columbia University.

Caleb is responsible for connecting African high school students to college students and professionals in America. His goal is to impact the next generation of African youths to provide opportunities for themselves and others. 


  Primrose E Nyahwai


Primrose Nyahwai is a senior, majoring in Accounting and International Business at Keuka College. For EA, she works in the capacity of the Treasurer where she created the whole Treasury Function, created statutory policies regarding this function, and continues to advice the organization regarding strategies on improving liquidity through cutting excess expenditure and boosting revenues. Outside the areas of her degree program, she is also interested in understanding cultures, environmental sustainability, youth empowerment, and eradication of poverty through the creation of job opportunities. This led her to go on study abroad program in China where she not only studied the local culture and language, but also identified business opportunities and created small partnerships that she hopes will enable her to start on a project she can implement to create jobs in the foreseeable future. Whilst there, she also initiated a sustainability program whose aim was on identifying more ways of sustaining the environment for future generations. Primrose also enjoys blogging and she is an extrovert.

She is inspired not by wealthy people with billions of dollars in their bank accounts, but by those poor hardworking vendors on the streets, in hostile weather conditions, trying to earn a living for their families. One of her favorite quotes is by Thomas Jefferson: “it is neither wealth nor splendor; but tranquility and occupation which gives you happiness.”


  Tongai Makoni

"Tongai Makoni recently graduated with a Master in Public Administration at Cornell University where he concentrated in science, technology and infrastructure policy. He is a fellow of the Institute for African Development, Telluride Scholar, and a Reese Miller Scholarship recipient. He is interested in the field of development; particularly incentivizing investment infrastructure, education, and private sector development in Zimbabwe. 

His goal is to contribute in creating mechanisms that allow people to earn their way out of poverty and in turn promote economic stability and prosperity in Africa."


  Samantha Kelly


Samantha Kelly is a Biology and Spanish graduate from Spelman College. She has worked in the molecular lab to find out the sexual behavior of a newly named species of amoeba. Her hard work awarded her with the honor of being a co-author of a scientific paper in the Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology in 2012.

A first generation college student she is dedicated to assisting others their dreams through formal and informal education.


  Sayoko “Mama K” Duhe


Sayoko (“Mama K”) Duhe Watson, is an advocate dedicated to supporting the educational dreams and aspirations of women and youth around the world. Utilizing behavioral, social, and cultural interventions, she designed programs, curriculum, and managed services at organizations and institutions seeking to empower youth and families. She has also conducted research in the areas of youth development, Africana Studies, and HIV/AIDS and substance abuse prevention.  Sayoko holds a B.A. in Social Science from San Francisco State University, and an M.A. in Education with an emphasis in Multicultural Counseling from San Diego State University.

Sayoko currently serves on the board of the Bay Area Association of Black Psychologists, and is a consultant and global board member of Emergination Africa.


  Donald Mlambo


Donald is an Analyst in the IT Advisory Department with KPMG Zimbabwe. He is the champion on the ground in Zimbabwe His roles include coordinating student activities and getting feedback from our mentees and making sure mentees receive the support and guidance they need


  Ryan Rumano

Driven and passionate aspiring engineer. Seeks to push his comfort zone and better himself and believes its more of heart and will that can help a person achieve their goals than current circumstances.


  Rufaro Madamombe

At only 19 years old, Rufaro is the youngest and newest addition to the Emergination Africa team. She finished high school at St Ignatius College last year passing her national examinations with flying colors. She's an aspiring lawyer who is starting university next year. Her passion to nurture the next generation leaders & help people especially the youth is what attracted her to Emergination Africa in the first place. She strongly believes in the potential that the African youth have to one day create a better African continent & commends Emergination Africa in their effort to mould this youth potential through both education & mentorship. A very active member of Emergination Africa (Zim team) who is trying her hardest to be the change she wants to see in the world not only for herself but for the greater good at large. 

A philanthropist by heart who by the grace of God will one day send orphans to school and open libraries in 3rd world countries. Look for me in 10 years time.

HOW WE PLAN TO HELP - THE PROGRAM OVERVIEW 

Our Program is based on 4 Pillars;

·  Career Advice and Support

·  College Application Process

·  Global Networking

·  Community Engagement

Through our Emerging Fellows program we connect high school students to college students and professionals around the world through bi-weekly one on one video call sessions, panel discussions and project based learning activities.

We pride ourselves in providing our students with the global educational and professional resources that set them apart as growing global citizens.

THE PROCESS

Under our College Application Process our students spend a minimum of one hour per week over video calls with a U.S. college mentor going over curriculum goals and activities that aid the student in identifying a degree, understanding the different types of Universities that exist and applying to them.

In between these sessions mentees also have the opportunity to talk to University admissions officers to learn more about the universities and what they look for.

Through Career Advisement mentees work with their mentors in developing their resumes, cover letters and exploring and identifying careers they would be interested in.

Our Emerging Fellows Program sessions nurture Global Networking as students get a chance to network and learn from professionals and college students in the USA, and other parts of the world.

We put a strong emphasis on our mentees using the knowledge they have learned to create on campus projects and information sessions where they impart one or two of our programmatic objectives to the entire student body, as well as in their communities.

Our Community Development piece enables such interactions.


SOME OF OUR SUCCESS STORIES SO FAR...


Our Goal is to raise  $25,000 through this crowdfunding campaign to meet our organizational needs for the coming 2 fiscal years.

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE USED

The money raised will provide funding for;

  • Data and Internet Services
    • Program Budget: $ 3000/year
  • College Entry Exam Fees/SAT Scholarships
    • Program Budget: $ 1000/year
  • College Application Fees
    • Program Budget: $950/year
  • Hardware for Communication e.g. Laptops
    • $1000/year
  • Establishment of Learning Hubs
    • $9000/6 Hubs/One-Time

  • Operating Costs: Learning Hubs
    • $2000/6 Hubs/ year

What’s Next For Us?

·  2016

o  Establish 25 EmergiHubs across Zimbabwe

o  Launch EmergiTours Program

·  2017

o  Expansion of Emerging Fellows Program

o Zambia

o Lesotho

·  2018

o  Launch EmergiTechies Program

o  Launch EmergiPreneurs Program

PERKS/REWARDS

When you support our campaign, we want to reward you for your support and generosity.

We have tons of great Perks for our supporters. For all the details, check the column on the right.



SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN WITH YOUR NETWORK

Whether you can support financially or not - all of your help is much appreciated. 

If you like what we are doing and want to help us to reach our goal then please share this campaign using the Indiegogo tools above on the left.

Tell everyone you know about the importance of Higher Education and spread the good news about our aims and objectives here at Emergination Africa

Blog about us

Post a message about us on Facebook 

Get involved in anyway you can

Tweet using the hashtag #EmerginationAfrica 

Send an Email to your colleges, peers and class mates about the opportunities we have to offer through our EmergiHubs

For further information on the campaign and regarding your perks please contact us on

Contact: princeabudu@gmail.com

story:
Where can a small contribution do the most good? 

Where can a small amount of money create the most opportunity?

For the price of a cup of coffee, a sandwich, a bottle of wine or a dinner out on the town, you can chip in to truly change the life of a child. A lot of people giving a little bit... It would mean the world to some wonderful kids!

The argument here is that educational opportunity can be purchased at a small cost and can lead to radical change in the life of a child, a family, a community, a city and our world.

Indonesia is the 4th largest country in our world. It is a democracy and a place where social mobility though education can happen. Jakarta, on the Island of Java, is one of the five largest urban centers on Earth. This city of more than 20 million is a place where Christian and Muslims coexist in peace within communities. It is also a place where pollution and poverty stand in the way of the dreams of too many children.

We invite you to join us. We are a small group of American and Indonesian friends who are on a mission to do something positive. The overall goal of our project is to give underprivileged children in urban Jakarta a chance at a true college preparatory experience.  In the fall of 2014, we began to open our first school and our first two urban education centers. We hope to generate a student population that is academically empowered to pursue higher education in the United States, Europe or Australia. They will return home with the ability to create enormous projects of positive change in their communities as engineers, scientists, doctors, journalists, teachers and more!

For this particular fundraising project, we are attempting to raise $4,000 to fund  the purchase of 10 ipads to equip a computer lab in one of our sisters schools just outside of Jakarta. This will give these students the chance to take advantage of all the web has to offer, along with FREE on-line classes and access to great teachers! This simple lab can change the direction of their lives! It is so inexpensive to give them the world!

Every penny counts. Thank you for doing the right thing each day, regardless of what you consider that to be.

If you have any questions about this project, if you are interested in joining our team, or contributing your talents in any way, PLEASE contact us! info@greenschooljakarta.com

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has." - Margaret Meade

Terima kasih! 

Please tell your friends!
story_txt: Where can a small contribution do the most good? Where can a small amount of money create the most opportunity?For the price of a cup of coffee, a sandwich, a bottle of wine or a dinner out on the town, you can chip in to truly change the life of a child. A lot of people giving a little bit... It would mean the world to some wonderful kids!The argument here is that educational opportunity can be purchased at a small cost and can lead to radical change in the life of a child, a family, a community, a city and our world.Indonesia is the 4th largest country in our world. It is a democracy and a place where social mobility though education can happen. Jakarta, on the Island of Java, is one of the five largest urban centers on Earth. This city of more than 20 million is a place where Christian and Muslims coexist in peace within communities. It is also a place where pollution and poverty stand in the way of the dreams of too many children.We invite you to join us. We are a small group of American and Indonesian friends who are on a mission to do something positive. The overall goal of our project is to give underprivileged children in urban Jakarta a chance at a true college preparatory experience.  In the fall of 2014, we began to open our first school and our first two urban education centers. We hope to generate a student population that is academically empowered to pursue higher education in the United States, Europe or Australia. They will return home with the ability to create enormous projects of positive change in their communities as engineers, scientists, doctors, journalists, teachers and more!For this particular fundraising project, we are attempting to raise $4,000 to fund  the purchase of 10 ipads to equip a computer lab in one of our sisters schools just outside of Jakarta. This will give these students the chance to take advantage of all the web has to offer, along with FREE on-line classes and access to great teachers! This simple lab can change the direction of their lives! It is so inexpensive to give them the world!Every penny counts. Thank you for doing the right thing each day, regardless of what you consider that to be.If you have any questions about this project, if you are interested in joining our team, or contributing your talents in any way, PLEASE contact us! info@greenschooljakarta.com"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has." - Margaret MeadeTerima kasih! Please tell your friends!

story:
The Committee to End the CSI Refuge Center is a non-profit educational organization. We are a 527 PAC in the eyes of the IRS. The Committee seeks to bring into its membership only men and women of good character, humane conscience, and religious ideals. We strive to set an example — in words and deeds — by dedication, integrity, and purpose, which future generations may follow without hesitation.

The object of the Committee shall be to End the CSI Refugee Center by creating an informed electorate through programs of education and action.

There are things that our society cannot tolerate and expect to survive.  Justice must take its rightful place above tolerance.

REFUGEE RESETTLEMENT AN EXISTENTIAL NATIONAL SECURITY THREAT:

The federal Refugee Resettlement  program is operated today by the Global Left, the United Nations, radical Islam, and religious frauds. The goal is to change the demographic composition of the population thereby changing America. As a result, we are drowning in refugees who are destroying our Constitutional freedoms, overburdening our welfare system and posing a genuine national security threat.

The U.S. Department of State approves the number of refugees coming to Twin Falls County and it has been reported that up to 300 refugees are coming to Twin Falls County from Syria a “failed state” known to have ISIS terrorists.  ISIS terrorists have indicated they will use the refugee program to bring in their Jihadists.  ISIS is recruiting on the Internet and we see that happening in Idaho and around the country.  There are 15 more Islamic Jihad terrorist groups also recruiting in America.

The FBI’s deputy assistant director of counter-terrorism, testified before a House Homeland Security committee in February 2015 and said it was virtually impossible to screen refugees from Syria a “failed state” , where the U.S. does not have boots on the ground and does not have access to reliable police or intelligence records.

From a financial standpoint, every dollar in profit that a refugee center earns for trafficking refugees represents many dollars in external costs that is foisted upon Twin Falls County citizens, especially increased education and welfare costs.

 Over $249,356.00 in state and local taxes spent every year to instruct refugee students in Twin Falls School System.  This does not include Federal Tax funds that are spent on the refugee students.

The Twin Falls schools have more than 224 refugee students and over 19 languages are spoken at a great cost of ESL Staff.

Voluntary Agency (VOLAG) – The College of Southern Idaho (CSI) a public, non-profit resettlement contractor, received $1,300,000.00 debt based money in 2014 to resettle about 300 refugees, & asylees.

CSI used both local and taxes from the State legislature to fund a $650,000.00 Refugee Center Complex off campus without the express authorization of the legislature or the Idaho Code.  It also pays it self (CSI)  $3,000.00 in rent using funds from a Federal Grant.

CSI used both local and taxes from the State legislature to fund off campus homes and apartments it uses to house refugees in without the express authorization of the legislature or the Idaho Code.  CSI then turns around and gives the Refugees Federal Grant money to pay the monthly rent back to CSI.

From a financial standpoint, every dollar that refugee center receives for trafficking refugees represents a dollar that is ultimately added to the Federal debt, violating the belief of many citizens regarding government debt spending.

We believe Twin Falls County faces epidemic welfare fraud, petty crime, polygamy, gang, drug and assimilation problems among local refugees. The local refugee center is failing to properly insure all of its clients are attaining family self-sufficiency and adjustment to life in America. Currently there are over 100 destitute refugees that desperately need help. Local churches  have been over loaded with requests for help and;

The people of  Twin Falls County, Idaho are working to  enact an ordinance using the  initiative process for the May 2016 ballot.

Mr. Obama is using resettlement to dilute GOP influence in Idaho.

Refugee populations use welfare at vastly higher rates than U.S. citizens:

REFUGEE RESETTLEMENT PROGRAM OUT OF CONTROL:

Increased 4000% from 2000 

Refugee vs U.S. Households Percentage on Welfare Households

Refugees vs. U.S. Citizens

Cash Assistance 37.8%/  2.9%

Food Stamps 61.0%/  13.1%

SSI 14.8%/  2.6%

Medicaid 48.4%/  16.0%

TANF 17.8%/  1.4%

Sources: Census Bureau, SSA, USDA, ORR

Current Donation Goals for Our Campaign To End the College Of Southern Idaho Refugee Center;

1. Printing of Education Action Kits and Petitions for Ballot Measure $1000.00

2.  Postage $500.00

3.  One (4) weeks pay for Executive Director (80 hours) - $1,200.00

4.  Consultant fee's for Ballot Measure - $300.00

For More Information Call Rick Martin at 208-329-6973

story:
Short Summary

Vegetable Circus is a program of the Allied Wellness Education Network, a 501(c)3 non-profit. It is our mission to connect circus arts training with eating a daily variety of vegetables in order to teach children fun ways to grow up healthy. Interactive assembly shows, structured multi-week enrichment programs, and hands-on workshops educate kids about living healthy in engaging and confidence-raising ways that support their development. Since 2005, Vegetable Circus has expanded to offer services to schools and community organizations across America. Our most active regions are New England, North Carolina, and California. Between 2012 and 2015 Vegetable Circus performed over 200 assembly shows and provided over 1,500 hours of after school enrichment programming in Elementary schools across the country delivering our wellness message to over 60,000 children!

Demand continues to grow for Vegetable Circus services in communities across America and it is necessary to maintain a national liability insurance policy. As a non-profit organization with expanding overhead costs, we need your help! Your support helps Vegetable Circus offer nurturing and enriching services to children, families, and schools across America!

What We Need

Our funding goal is $1,500 and 100% of your donations will go directly to renewing the Vegetable Circus national liability insurance policy. This is vital to ongoing Vegetable Circus services at many elementary schools and also to the expansion of Vegetable Circus services into new communities. If we exceed our funding goal, additional money raised will go to new equipment for Vegetable Circus assembly shows and enrichment programs.

What You Get

In addition to the satisfaction you will have knowing that you contributed to enriching young student lives, you will receive a receipt from Firstgiving.com which authenticates your donation as tax deductible. You will also receive one of many unique perks with your donation. Our perks offer a large variety of items and services that also make spectacular gifts!

The Impact

Vegetable Circus inspires children to make healthy decisions and take care of their growing bodies. Vegetable Circus services teach children the three ingredients to healthy living which are healthy eating, healthy moving, and healthy hydration.

With a growing epidemic of child obesity, it is imperative to bring this message of wellness to schools and communities across the nation. We have received feedback from children, parents, school faculty, and community event organizers that Vegetable Circus services get children excited about living and eating healthy. We frequently hear that Vegetable Circus programs stimulate children more than the average program and leaves a lasting impression on children. This fundraiser will help Vegetable Circus expand enriching services to schools and communities across America!

Other Ways You Can Help

Every small donation counts! Even if 75 people donate just $20 each, we will have met our fundraising goal! We know that some fans may not be able to contribute at this time, and that is okay because you can still help! Make some noise about our campaign and share it with your friends, family, co-workers, school affiliates, and whomever else you think would help contribute. Share our Indiegogo page on social media sites and support our worthy cause! Thank you so much for all of your support and contributions! We greatly appreciate every effort!

story:
This campaign supports grassroots education projects in the Amazon, Panama, and India to keep girls and boys in school. While cost of tuition is relatively low, families with limited resources often have to make tough choices between sending their kids to school and providing basic necessities. 

According to development research and UN reports, universal education and gender equity are the top two priorities to eradicate global poverty - investing in women is one of the most effective means to reduce poverty in developing countries.

Mona Foundation believes that the key to eliminating poverty and achieving positive community transformation lies in universal education, gender equality, and cultivating the potential of children.

Send Kids Around the World Back to School!

It costs an average of $500 to keep one child in school for one year in the Amazon, Panama, and India. This $500 pays for scholarships, uniforms, teacher training, school supplies, and lunches. (That’s just over $40/month.) However, for some families, this is a financial hardship or even an impossibility. Mona Foundation provides support to grassroots educational initiatives all over the world that keep over 75,000 kids in school each year - help us send kids back to school in 2016!

   

Our goal is to provide support for 4 Mona Foundation programs: ADCAM, Badi School, Barli Development Institute for Rural Women, and Digital Study Hall. Each has a proven track record of:

  • Improving the social and economic life of the community as a whole, with an emphasis on women and girls
  • Empowering children to become agents of change and community citizens committed to serving humanity
  • Deeply committed to meeting the long-term needs of their community, with proven records of success 

   

Impact of Universal Education and Gender Equality

Education and gender equality are core strategies of our work because:

  • In developing countries an extra year of primary school boosts girls’ eventual wages by 10 to 20 percent. An extra year of secondary: 15 to 25 percent. Educated girls grow into educated women, and research shows that they have healthier babies and are more likely to share what they’ve learned with their families, children and communities.
  • Investing in women is often found to be the most effective means to reduce poverty in developing countries. World Bank data demonstrates that gender equality and economic development are inextricably linked. Equality not only guarantees basic rights but also plays a vital role in promoting the robust, shared growth needed to end extreme poverty.

Education transforms the lives of children, their families, and their communities. When kids see how their futures change when they get an education, they want to help others:

“Kids like me worked in the streets doing any little thing we could to earn money. Because I get a chance to take this course, I’ve leaped ahead of many people. It’s not to leave them behind, but to be able to help them later on to also pursue their dreams.” - Bruna (ADCAM)

“In future, the education we receive will also benefit others, just as we have been benefited, because we’ll be more able to offer help and give back.” – Paulo (ADCAM)

“I am happy to see a new self confidence in my sister. Now she has the courage to express herself in front of others without any fear. I firmly believe that if women are given equal opportunities, they can excel in every sphere of life.” - Alka’s brother (Barli)

The Schools

ADCAM (Association for the Cohesive Development of the Amazon) in Manaus, Brazil - the heart of the Amazon rainforest - has over 30 years of experience supporting children to become agents of change  in their communities. ADCAM started as a small orphanage with 30 kids and in response to community needs, has grown to include:  a full K-12 school, a technical institute to teach job skills, community outreach programs for street kids and poor families and rural tutorial education for river villages in the interior of the Amazon. ADCAM programs serve 4,000 people each day.  Children who’ve gone through ADCAM’s programs come back to serve their communities as adults and raise their own children with service to humanity as one of their highest values. 

Badi School in Panama educates the poorest children, many from indigenous backgrounds. The school  started as a kindergarten in the carport of a family that wanted to serve their community.  Over the years, it's grown into an institution offering classes through 12th grade, serving over 400 students annually. Scholarships are particularly important to the students of Badi School. Although school is free in Panama and compulsory for children between the ages of six and fifteen, nearly half the children in the San Miguelito area do not have access to education. Badi School is recognized for its academic excellence throughout Panama and by various organizations such as the Ibero-American Council of Education (which represents over 400 educational institutions in Latin America, Spain and the U.S.). 

Barli Institute for the Development of Rural Women in Indore, India educates girls and young women from the lowest castes and scheduled tribes, who learn to read and write in six months and become proficient in a trade like tailoring. During the six-month training, the girls become literate, learn a trade, and probably most importantly, leave with a desire to serve their communities. Over 90% of Barli graduates are now working towards positive social change in their home villages. Studies have shown that Barli graduates create a new atmosphere of respect and unity in their communities, helping to displace caste and gender prejudices.

Digital Study Hall, headquartered in Lucknow, India, uses “lite tech” and innovative approaches to disseminate video lessons to rural and slum schools. Digital Study Hall’s mission is to improve the quality of education, reaching thousands of disadvantaged children in central India. The best grassroots teachers are filmed as they teach the local state curriculum in their local languages. Lesson videos are shared with poor schools which are given TVs, players and electrical equipment. They also provide programming and training to government girls’ schools and District Institutes of Educational Training (DIETs) to train student teachers. 

The Budget

This campaign will raise funds to cover education costs in the Amazon, Panama, and India. These costs include scholarships, books, meals, materials, uniforms, outings, vocational and arts programs, technology, teacher trainings, and more!

Perks

To thank you for your support for this project, we are offering some exclusive perks to donors:

Signed headshot of Mona Foundation Board Member and actor Rainn Wilson

Mona Foundation tote bag - show your support for universal education in style as you carry groceries, library books, school supplies, and more!

Invitation to an intimate event with Badi School Co-Founder, Oscar Torrez in Seattle, WA in early October, 2015 

    View Mr. Torrez's Bio online

2 tickets to Mona Foundation's 16th Annual Celebration Dinner in Seattle, WA on October 10th, 2015 including a private reception with Rainn Wilson and Oscar Torrez.

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Like and share our campaign link on Facebook or Twitter, and tell people about it - word of mouth works!

2. Send an email to your friends, family, or colleagues to tell them about this important project

3. Sign up for our newsletter to stay up to date on Mona Foundation's grassroots educational initiatives in the Amazon, Panama, India, and around the world!

About Us

Mona Foundation is a 501(c) (3) non-profit organization that supports grassroots educational initiatives which emphasize service to the community and increased opportunity for women and girls in the US and abroad. We believe that universal education and gender equality are the cornerstones for the eradication of poverty. 

We pursue these principles by offering support to grassroots educational initiatives in many countries. The board of directors travels the world to identify schools that meet our funding criteria. Since 1999, Mona Foundation has provided $8 million to 34 educational initiatives in 16 countries and quality education to more than 75,000 children annually.

story:
Most of us are blessed and raised in a land of endless opportunities, and given the right tools to succeed to benefit in our own lives. Others around the world are not so lucky. After traveling to 15 countries in 4 months I realized that in most countries there is a huge lack of opportunity and I want to change that! 

I was fortunate enough to grow up in a very loving home, with parents who provided me with a chance to live a wonderful life, a full belly and who have inspired me and taught me it's important to give back to those in need. I wan't to provide opportunity to the kids that have the skill but have little chance to get to where they want and have the potential to be. I want to help inspire and provide a chance to someone that needs it and for so little we can make a huge difference in someones life. 

We were fortunate to be given that chance from someone in our lives. So in turn…why shouldn’t we pay-it-forward by feeding 500 children for an entire year? 

This program has been running successfully for 4 years now. Please help us keep it going. 

I'm coming forward and asking for everyone's help in raising $5800 in ONLY 7 days! (Every $1 counts!! Only $16 will feed 1 child for an entire year)

By following the link below you will be able to see pictures and video from past trips :)    www.facebook.com/ProjectSolutionJamaica

Where Does The Money Go:

We would like to make it very clear that 100% of the money raised during this campaign goes directly into the children's breakfast fund at Granville Primary School located in Trelawny, Jamaica. Any additional funds raised will go towards the scholarship program, where only $1400 can fund one child’s tuition, food and room and board for 1 year. 

An example of just how far your money will go, can be seen in the reviving of the breakfast program: There are approximately 500 children dependent on this program. The breakdown is this: to feed 500 children each morning for one year will only cost approximately $5800! We can make this difference! We've been helping for 4 years now...let's continue to show we care ☺ 

At the end of the campaign all donators will be entered into a draw to win a Photoshoot valued at $500 with Natalia Anja Photography. 

Thank you for your support!

story:
To Know, to Grow, to Act: Changing Perceptions of Youth

These days, the youth in Palestine/Israel face growing challenges. The loss of hope results in fear, anger and frustration leading to racism and violence. Windows' youth refuse to accept the tension that previous generations have left with them.

They are ready to work towards a future based on justice and equality, living together or side by side. Last year's support for Windows' enabled them to meet, learn, and develop a courageous blog together. Now, a new generation of Israeli and Palestinian youth are preparing the Windows Media Program. The preparation process will allow them to create perceptions that impact the media. We need your help to make a difference. Your support will reach thousands of youth who may begin to think in a different way!

                                                             

                   Support the new generation of Windows' Youth:                                                    Help them create Alternative Media    

We urge you all to support our "2016 Youth Media and Action Program". Seventeen new participants, from both sides of the Green Line – Jaffa, Tel Aviv, and Bet Omar (near Hebron) – will form a new generation of Windows' youth and begin a two-year empowerment process to create alternative media and become young leaders in their communities.

Your investment in Windows’ youth has a long-term effect: following the initial two year program, participants remain active in Windows. With their skills and knowledge they will initiate and lead more activities for their peers in the youth-led “Open Spaces for Youth" programs. As they grow up they become an active part of the local civil society that works towards justice and peace.

               

               This year program follows the success of the last year

Following the success of our summer 2014 Indiegogo campaign, “The Youth Who Won’t Give Up”, we raised over $16,000 and were able to complete our 2014-2015 program.  Seventeen youth from Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories (namely from Jaffa, Tel Aviv. and Nablus) were provided with a safe space to process their feelings and experiences in single identity group sessions and several multi-day bi-national seminars. During the program, they learned about the past and present of our region, discussed a shared future based on democracy and equality, and debated potential solutions based on these values.

In spite of the pain and sadness that we all share over the recent events around the Middle East and all over the world, Windows’ youth are determined to continue their search for the truth about our complex reality and to bravely deal with this reality while finding new and creative ways to promote a better future for all. In the toughest of times, they understand the value of open channels of communication so they can share the news on the ground with a wider audience.

                              

                               The News: "In Front of the Mirror",                                                              The Youth Blog Searching for the Truth

Windows' youth established "In Front of the Mirror", a blog that publishes their thoughts and feelings about recent events as well as information compiled from their research projects. The blog invites both those who agree and disagree with the content to engage in a constructive discussion and learn from each other. All articles and posts are written in/translated to Arabic, Hebrew and English; guest writers add more voices to those of the core group.

Windows' education team prepares lesson plans based on the blog's content to be used by educators trained by the Windows team. Schools approach Windows to benefit from our many years of experience in the field and programs are beginning now in several schools.

We wish to thank those who donated to the last campaign – without you, these achievements would have not been possible.

                              


                                  What Funding is needed for?

Windows has raised a portion of the $21,000 USD needed for the "2016 Youth Media and Action Program". However, an additional $15,000 USD are needed to cover the full cost. This amount covers the youth weekly uni-national meetings and the periodical bi-national seminars as well as the trainings and supervision of the facilitators. It also enables the Windows youth to maintain the Arabic-Hebrew blog – one of the outcomes of Windows' 2014 Indiegogo campaign.

                        


                          About Windows: A Unique Organization

Windows: Channels for Communication is a grassroots non-profit organization comprised of Palestinians from both sides of the Green Line, Israelis and internationals. We all share the belief that it is possible to create a future in our region that is based on democracy, equality, freedom and safety for all.

Established in 1991, Windows has unique experience in developing and implementing long term educational programs that address the imbalance of power between the sides and the core issues. Our programs empower youth to work together and separately towards ending the occupation, oppression, discrimination and other violations of human rights.

                           


The Impact of Windows Programs: A Long-Term Cognitive Change

No agreement between political leaders is sustainable without a profound and positive change in the way we see ourselves, each other, and the complexities between us. High quality education programs are necessary in order to create a change of perceptions on a wider scale—Windows offers well-established programs to meet this need.

Unlike Europe and the USA, in Israel/Palestine youth make up a big part of the local societies, and soon enough they will have the power to shape their future. It is our responsibility to empower them to reach justice, well-being, and peace.

               

                       Challenges: Moving from Despair to Hope

The risks and obstacles we face are primarily the growing despair and loss of hope on both sides that lead to objections to our joint activities. Windows' youth are determined to do all they can towards ending the situation in which they are not equal, but occupied and occupier – a situation they did not choose to be in but were born into. 

Support their efforts!


Find the Youth Blog on: https://infrontofthemirroreng.wordpress.com/

story:
Sunday in the Park with George in Austin Tx

is a beautiful musical by Stephen Sondheim.  We are staging a concert version with professional (Actors Equity) actors and orchestra.  With your help we can underwrite student tickets to the show at the Long Center's beautiful Rollins Theater.  You can help more young music students experience this wonderful show!  The project is funded by Austin Shakespeare (501 c 3 non profit) and Armstrong Community Music School.


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $2,000 will underwrite low priced tickets for 100 students; if we exceed our goal we can underwrite more student tickets. You can receive some perks including our unique poster or

    •  magnet
    •  key chains 
    •  luggage tag of Seurat's famous painting
    • signed poster by Mackenzie Dunn
    • your name in the program
    • If we don't reach our entire goal, we will get as many students to see the show that we have underwritten.

What a difference you make!

Young people who have experienced this show have been personally inspired by the creative life portrayed 

  • Spread positive values of joy in music and art
  • We have had two successful Indiegogo campaigns over the past two years

We can meet the challenge

ACMS scholarship students are already coming to see the show but we want to share with more kids and the six colleges in the Austin surrounding area.

  • Collaborating with the Long Center we have outreach to young audiences 
  • We hope to bring love of Sondheim's music to the next generation.

Help Spread the Word

  • Like Austin Shakespeare on Facebook and spread the word on "Sondheim's Sunday in the Park with George"
  • Use Indiegogo share tools!
  • Follow AustinShakes #sundayinthepark on twitter

Thanks for spreading the joy!

story:
Beakur

Looking for citizen science stewards

Beakur is an Android application designed to help people conduct citizen science experiments of their own design as well as join other projects. It's goal is to offer the tools for creation of projects as well as connectivity to an audience that will aid in the projects success.

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.beakur

Democratization of science participation and the creation of an enjoyable environment that encourages participation or spawns new ideas is a goal of Beakur.

We will to have some serious projects and offer partnerships with existing citizen science projects as well as creation of projects of a less serious nature. Through participation, we hope to create a greater interest in science and better understanding of its goals. Like a youth learning some basic statistics and math by reading the sports page, participation and fun are a goal.

The goals for this campaign are to continue development of the web application and IOS versions. The Android version is in a soft release phase, please check it out and give feedback.

What We Need & What You Get

I am a single developer and need help creating some awareness of the project as well as cover the cost of servers and some development needs. Though, I do all of the programming myself, there are charges associated with space and additional contracting help.

The Impact

 The world becomes more educated and aware of scientific knowledge.

Democratizing the scientific experience by giving tools and access to an audience that will assist you in your projects.

story:
The Cause

Hunger, Drugs, Violence, Gangs. 

Every day, children in poverty are confronted with experiences and decisions that are well beyond their years, shaping them into a person they shouldn't have to become. They face unspeakable things that no child should ever face. They spend every second of their time fighting away the bad and searching for the good, but without a sense of hope, the moment arrives where it becomes so much easier to lose the thought of a different, brighter future for themselves, so much easier to be recruited into gangs because there's nowhere else to go, so much easier to fall into an even worse situation because there's no one else to turn to for help.

Before this moment can happen, a charitable organization called Toronto Youth Development reaches out their hand and pulls these children out of poverty's grasp. For 20 years, TYD has dedicated its time to being an escape for at-risk youth. 

With proper character formation, peer mentoring, access to education, organized sports, many trips, summer and winter camps, and the help of donations to keep it ALL going, Toronto Youth Development has allowed thousands of children and youth to see the potential in themselves, dream big and continue on to a College or University education to open the doors that would otherwise be closed to them. 

The Mission!

Through organized sports, we see the greatest change in the kids that come to play. To some it's a great time to be active, make new friends, and learn new skills every day. To others, it's a life saver. 

Through academics, these children are offered a chance to receive a post-secondary education and every step of the learning process is supported by TYDs teachers and tutors. 

These two things are what encompass Toronto Youth Development's ASE (Academic and Sports Enrichment) Summer Program and it's the desperate need to keep this program running, that is what's fueling this campaign.  

To make it clear what your donations will be put towards: 

  • ASE Summer Program including:
  • Keeping the Academic Program running
  • Keeping the Regent Park Soccer League (more than 300 kids registered) running
  • Funding as many more kids as possible for this summer program
  • Starting a brand new Basketball League for the fall! 
Please help TYD continue to keep children off the streets with your donations. 

What We Need & What You Get!

What we need is simple. We need to reach our goal of $10 000 within the next 60 days! The more money raised, the more children can be registered into the ASE Summer Program that will change their lives forever! 

But just to add a few perks, we've decided to create a draw! For every $10 you donate you get one entry into a draw to win AWESOME prizes from these generous donors below! 
- $100 gift card from Harpers Landing Restaurant
- $100 gift card from Williams Landing Restaurant
- $100 gift card from Hunters Landing Restaurant
- 200 (50x4 winners) free slice coupons from Pizza Pizza 
- 4 (2x2 winners) movie passes from Cineplex Entertainment
-$100 gift card from Subway 
And much more to come! 

       

                                            


The more you donate, the higher the chance of winning! 

Visit https://www.facebook.com/TYDcampaignofhope to find out more about these prizes are and who wins them at the end of the campaign! 
Remember if you want to be entered into the contest don't hide your name when you make a contribution and either like the Facebook page or send us your contact info so we can send you your prizes if you win! 

Hear Their Stories

Want to know more about TYD and the people who help run it? These stories will be shared on our Facebook page. Keep an eye out for these upcoming profiles and share their stories as far and wide as you can! 

Visit https://www.facebook.com/TYDcampaignofhope to hear more about the stories I've heard and will be sharing with you. 

We Can Do This... But Not Without You!  

We have 60 days to reach $10 000! This is important. We need your help to spread this campaign as far and wide as humanly possible and we need your donations to keep the programs that so many children rely on, running, and start something new! Your donations are the most valuable thing you can give this charitable organization!! Should we not reach our campaign goal, your donations will not be lost, any funding raised will still be donated to TYD. 

Can't Contribute? It's Alright! 

If you can't contribute it's alright! Help us in other ways by spreading this campaign to all your friends and family! Use the share tools on Indiegogo or like and share our campaign Facebook page! Please help us get this message out! 

https://www.facebook.com/TYDcampaignofhope

story:
ABOUT PAGES (www.pages.com.ng)


The project Pages Nigeria is bent around the paradigm "Getting ideas and thoughts more valuable". What initiated the project was that lots of African youths, especially students are always in search of alternative sources of income to support themselves most especially while in school, We don't have the opportunity to work and study like in the western world. I was also a victim of this circumstance and most of us ends up engaging in different crooked or illegals means of making money, A little study made showed that more blog websites are coming up these days that in almost every 20 homes, their is at-least someone interested in Blogging for income.

Pages Nigeria (www.pages.com.ng) is going to be a revenue sharing social media platform developed to provide a robust publishing tool for creating unlimited number of simple and useful blogs called "Pages" which will also earn the publisher some income as a reward.


                A picture of the current editing tool on www.pages.com.ng


Pages generates will generate income for its users through various advertising media partners.

This project is kick-starting from Nigeria and will be spread to every other parts of Africa and rest of the World.


HOW PAGES NIGERIA WORK

Practically, Pages works this way, a user has the ability to create an article (Page), this page can be shared with friends on other media networks, the creator (user) gets a reward for every unique visit of his article page. Income is been generated from adverts that will be displayed on one side of his blog page. More details can be gotten (Here)

                                                                 Published pages



INTERESTING THINGS ABOUT THIS PROJECT

Although their is in existence publishing tools like Blogger and Wordpress but all of these still requires a level of learning curve of how the system works. On Pages, users can publish their articles on the go and start earning almost immediately taking advantage of Pages traffic, search engine friendliness and social networks integration.


PROBLEM PAGES WILL SOLVE?

1 . It will provide alternative source of income for African youths so that they will no longer waste their useful time on social networks without any returns. Pages platform is aimed at engaging many African youth, this will translate to less joblessness and cyber crime.

2. Its is a common saying that when you want to hide a thing from Africans, you write it in a book. Pages Nigeria is kicking against this. It will encourage writing and reading culture of everyone especially the youths. Pages will make everyone reflective and also bring out the creativity and reflectivity in youths.


"For us to fix the World perfectly, Africa and infact Nigeria needs to be fixed because we have the highest concentration of black."




CURRENT FEATURES ON PAGES

  1. Connections - Users can subscribe to posts from other users by simply following them.

  2. Private messaging among users.


  3. Users profile page.

  4. Notification page - A page where user gets notified of events such as when they have new followers or comments.


  5. Earnings account page - A page to display user earnings

This will be much more than a social media network. The possibilities for this project stretch far beyond creating new pages and earning,  Here are some of the features that will soon be developed:


WHAT LIES IN THE FUTURE

  1. Messenger - There will be a state of the art AJAX instant messaging system that will allow one-on-one instant messaging session with friends. Only your followers will be able to message you, preventing any spam or messages from unwanted people. There will also be several easy to use setting giving you full control over your messaging experience.
  2. Voting - Give the power to the people! Any pages or article considered not relevant can be voted down, this will help readers to easily identify relevant content.
  3. Customization - The majority of the website design will be fully customizable. It is clear that some users prefer some layouts to others. There is no need to force everyone to have to same exact experience when using this website. Users will choose which features they prefer as well as many other fully customizable options.



CHALLENGES CURRENTLY FACED

Current challenges faced is capital to take the project to the implementation phase which includes spreading the word. Capital is also needed to put together a small team consisting of web developers and search engine optimization/marketing specialists. I single handedly worked on the project in 2013, It has been residing on my local host and i feel its time to take it to the next phase. In this regard the current website needs a little upgrading to meet up with current web technology in terms of usability, responsitivity and appearance. That is why am using this medium to ask for your support on the project in any little or massive way. Thank you.


Join in giving back hope to Africa

story:
A Small School with Lots of GIRL POWER!

  • We are a small non-profit all-girls school located in Kailua, Hawaii.
  • Your donations are tax-deductible.
  • We are raising money to travel to Kentucky to represent our state at the 2015 VEX World Championship - April 16-17-18
  • Your contribution will help send a team of four fabulous Butterflybotic Team Members and their coach to Louisville, Kentucky!

What We Need 

  • All funds collected will be evenly shared amongst the 3 girls to help defray travel costs (even if we don't reach our ultimate goal).
  • With your contribution you will be helping show the world that girls can be engineers too and can be competitive in the robotic field.

Pass it on!

  • Please share with others and help us reach our goal!
These girls not only create, build and  drive VEX IQ Robots, they produce a biweekly webcast video called MOXIE. They have created the video casts and MOXIE channel to get girls ages 5 - 12 inspired and excited about Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Math (S.T.E.A.M.). To ignite the fire of GIRL POWER all over the world!
View all of the MOXIE video produced so far here on the MOXIE VIMEO CHANNEL:
MOXIE VIDEO CHANNEL ON VIMEO

story:
My name is Syndi Knowlton. I am the mother of 3 special needs children living outside of Orem, Utah. In 2012, I started a Facebook page to help other families with special needs children to  ask questions their friends couldn't answer and a safe place to discuss difficult medical struggles.  Our common goal was to find the best resources, doctors, therapies and medicine for our children.

We began to swap spare medical supplies we no longer needed with families that had large out of pocket expenses or worse, no coverage.  It was truly a labor of love keeping up with this  mounting group.  In January 2014, with just over 500 families participating, we decided it was in everyone involved's best interest to  form a non profit.  This would give us the opportunity to tax deduct certain donations, credit for the tremendous mileage spent in relocating supplies, and access to grants to obtain more supplies our families were in need of.
By May 2014, our efforts were put into overdrive.  I was surprised to be honored as Special Needs Mother of the Year.  This gave us a huge publicity boost.  In August 2014, we called for a major supply round up.  We collected over $45,000 retail value of unneeded and unnecessary supplies.  At the end of 2014, we ended the year with just shy of 1300 families.


Our wish was granted in December 2014.  We became an official non profit!  The next logical step would be to get our name out there to every facility, clinic or doctor who could share the mission of Utah Kids with families that reach out looking for help.  This is where you come in.
Our Fundraising efforts will go to support:
  • Printing costs of promotional materials
  • Postage costs to supply these materials state wide
  • Complete the design and programming of our website
  • Give us an initial seed with which to secure a location and deposits for our first live fundraising efforts
Every dollar raised is going directly to the benefit of the Utah Kids Foundation.  All of the board members are fully volunteer.
To see our website, and to learn more about our mission, please visit our website located here.
